courses.name: Advancing Your Career Exploration Part I

cmCourseInfo.description: This preparatory course helps students navigate the challenges ahead in the world of Co-op and business. This course is highly interactive and practical, and is completed before students start seeking their Co-op work term opportunity. Management experienced Coordinators, and expert guests instruct students on how to succeed in their work terms. This course is a compulsory requirement for all Management Co-op programs. Students must pass this course before proceeding to seek for a work term opportunity, therefore, this course may be repeated.
cmCourseInfo.title: Advancing Your Career Exploration Part I
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: Restricted to students in the Management Co-op programs.
cmCourseInfo.note: Students in their first year Management Co-op Programs will be core-loaded into this course.

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Advancing Your Career Exploration (AYCE) is a mandatory course for all Management Co-op students prior to seeking for their first work-term. It is a credit requirement in addition to your BBA degree requirements and is not included in your cGPA. There are no tuition fees attached to this course. AYCE will begin the first week of classes.

For any questions regarding this class, please contact the Management Co-op office at 416.287.7111 or mgmtcoop.utsc@utoronto.ca

cmCourseInfo.description: This course is designed to prepare students in the International Development Studies Co-op programs with the skills, tools and experience to have a successful placement search. This course is an opportunity for students to explore the stages and dynamics of job searching, investigate various career options based on their skill set and interests, develop a placement search plan and create placement search documents. In addition, through workshops and events, students will have an opportunity to interact with IDS placement partners, senior students, and faculty, and gain insight into trends in the field of international development.
cmCourseInfo.title: Passport to Placement I
cmCourseInfo.note: Students should plan to complete this course in the first year of study in their selected IDS Co-op program.

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
The International Development Studies Co-op Placement Preparation Course (COPB30) is mandatory for all new students entering the co-op program. Students entering the program must take this course in their first year, in the Fall term. For students entering in their second year, they must take this course in the Fall term of their second year. This course is a prerequisite for COPB31. Students will automatically be enrolled in this course, but must ensure their timetable is clear for this registration. It is non-credit with no tuition fees attached.

NOTE: Students are responsible for ensuring they understand coop course requirements, and that they do not register for other courses during the time the coop course is offered. For any issues regarding the scheduling of this course, please contact the IDS co-op office as soon as possible at 416-287-7113 or ids-coop@utsc.utoronto.ca

Exclusion: COPD02H3

cmCourseInfo.description: In this course, students build upon skills and knowledge gained in COPB30H3. This course focuses on the job search and goal setting, culminating in students creating an Action Plan that focuses on developing and polishing their job search and application process skills in preparation for the Co-op application process in COPB33H3. By the end of this course, students should feel confident in their ability to network, write a job application, and communicate professionally.
cmCourseInfo.title: Passport to Placement II
cmCourseInfo.exclusionsText: (COPD04H3); COPB30H3 (if taken in Fall 2020 or earlier)
cmCourseInfo.note: IDS Co-op students must successfully complete this course prior to COPB33H3.

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
The International Development Studies Co-op Placement Preparation Course Part 2 (COPB31) is mandatory for all students to take in the winter term year prior to their placement (usually, year 2). Students will automatically be enrolled in this course, but must ensure their timetable is clear for this registration. It is non-credit with no tuition fees attached.

NOTE: Students are responsible for ensuring they understand coop course requirements, and that they do not register for other courses during the time the coop course is offered. For any issues regarding the scheduling of this course, please contact the IDS co-op office as soon as possible at 416-287-7113 or ids-coop@utsc.utoronto.ca

cmCourseInfo.description: This course is designed to prepare students in the International Development Studies Co-op programs with the skills, tools and preparation to be successful during the placement year. Building on the skills developed in the first two years of the program, students will explore placement opportunities based on their skill set and interests. The course will include presentations from International Development Studies placement partners, group exercises, and individual assignments designed to prepare students for the placement experience. Pre-departure orientation activities will include intercultural learning, health and safety issues, placement research, and other key topics. A weekend retreat with returned placement students (fifth-year) provides an opportunity for sharing first-hand experience and knowledge.
cmCourseInfo.title: Passport to Placement III
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: COPB30H3 and COPB31H3 (if taken Fall 2021 or later)

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
The International Development Studies Co-op Placement Preparation Course Part 3 (COPB33) is mandatory for all students to take in the year prior to their placement. Students will automatically be enrolled in this course, but must ensure their timetable is clear for this registration. It is non-credit with no tuition fees attached.

NOTE: Students are responsible for ensuring they understand coop course requirements, and that they do not register for other courses during the time the coop course is offered. For any issues regarding the scheduling of this course, please contact the IDS co-op office as soon as possible at 416-287-7113 or ids-coop@utsc.utoronto.ca

Exclusion: COPD04H3; COPB31H3 prior to Fall 2021

courses.name: Foundations for Success in Art and Science Co-op

cmCourseInfo.description: This course provides students in their first-year of Arts and Science Co-op to develop skills and tools to manage and thrive during the job search and in the workplace throughout the semester. In addition, students begin to build their job search tool kit, examine their strengths and areas of development, discover the skills employers are seeking in undergraduate Co-op students and in employees in general, and explore possible pathways to achieving their Co-op work terms and long term academic or career goals. Students will learn and practice strategies to best present their skills, knowledge and experience in foundational job search documents. The concept of interviewing is also introduced. This course is a compulsory requirement for the Arts and Science Co-op programs. Students need to pass the course before proceeding to seek for a Co-op work term, therefore, this course may be repeated.
cmCourseInfo.title: Foundations for Success in Arts and Science Co-op
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: Restricted to students in the Arts and Science Co-op programs.
cmCourseInfo.note: Students should plan to complete this course in the first year of study in their selected Arts and Science Co-op program.

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
ENROLLMENT CONTROL: R
Restricted to students in the first and second year of Co-op in Computer and Mathematical Sciences, Psychological & Health Sciences, Humanities & Social Sciences, French, Life Sciences, and Physical Environmental Sciences.

Arts & Science Co-op students admitted before Fall 2021 are automatically enrolled into the appropriate co-op courses each semester based on their program of study and co-op work term sequence. Students entering the co-op program in 2021-2022 onward will be required to enroll in the co-op course during their first year. Co-op courses are offered each semester.

The Co-op course will begin the first week of classes. It is non-credit with no tuition fees attached. If you have any questions regarding your enrolment please contact askcoop@utoronto.ca
LEC01 - Students admitted prior to Fall 2021
LEC02 - Co-op in Computer and Mathematical Sciences, Psychological & Health Sciences, Humanities & Social Sciences, French, Life Sciences, and Physical Environmental Sciences.
All PRA0001-0006 sessions start in 2nd week of classes and meet every other week.

courses.name: Preparing to Compete for your Co-op Work Term

cmCourseInfo.description: This course builds on the foundational job search concepts introduced in COPD01H3, providing opportunities to refine application strategies and practice interviewing in various formats, based on academic program areas as well as industry hiring practices. Students begin to experience the Co-op job search cycle by reviewing, selecting, and applying to job postings weekly and receiving feedback similar to when participating in a job search cycle. With this feedback, and the support of your Coordinator, students make adjustments to their job search approach and develop strategies for success in the following term for both job applications and interview performance. The importance of a job search network and research to tailor and prepare during your job search are also examined. This course is a compulsory requirement for the Arts and Science Co-op programs. Students need to pass the course before proceeding to seek for a Co-op work term, therefore, this course may be repeated.
cmCourseInfo.title: Preparing to Compete For Your Co-op Work Term
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: COPB50H3/(COPD01H3); restricted to students in the Arts and Science Co-op programs.

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
ENROLLMENT CONTROL: AR
Restricted to students in first or second year in an Arts & Science Co-op degree or subject POSt.

Permission of Arts & Science Co-op Department is required. You may select this course but will not be officially enrolled until approved. Check your status through ACORN to see whether you have been approved. (APP = approval; REF = refused; INT = no decision yet)

Arts & Science Co-op students admitted before Fall 2021 are automatically enrolled into the appropriate co-op courses each semester based on their program of study and co-op work term sequence. Students entering the co-op program in 2021-2022 onward will be required to enroll in the co-op course during their first year. Co-op courses are offered each semester.

It is non-credit with no tuition fees attached. If you have any questions regarding your enrolment please contact askcoop@utoronto.ca

Students will be enrolled/should enroll in the following sections based on their area of study:

LEC01 - Students admitted prior to Fall 2021
LEC02 - Humanities & Social Sciences Co-op, Physical and Environmental Sciences Co-op, Life Sciences Co-op, and Psychological and Health Sciences students in this LEC can enroll into PRA0001 or PRA0002
LEC03 - Computer Science Co-op, Mathematics Co-op, Statistics Co-op, Computer & Mathematical Sciences students can enroll into PRA0003 OR PRA0004.

Practicals start the first week of classes and run every other week

Students requests to enroll in the course will be reviewed at 3 points prior to the start of the semester and approval is based on successful completion of COPB50.

1st review: Mid July
2nd review: mid-late August (once grades from the summer term are available)
3rd review: early-mid September (before waitlist end date and last date to add course)

courses.name: Managing Your Job Search and Transition to Work

cmCourseInfo.description: This course will draw on students job search experience. Students will learn how to effectively and professionally navigate challenging situations while job searching and on work term. Drawing upon the job search knowledge and tool kit created in COPB50H2 and COPB51H3, this course is designed to provide students who are competing for a first Co‐op work term with resources and support necessary to meet their goal of securing a work term. During this semester, Co-op students are applying to job postings on CSM and attending interviews until they secure a work term. This course also provides students with job search trends, job search support and feedback, interview coaching, and peer activities. The course is a combination of in‐class, group activities, and one‐on‐one appointments. Topical information and insights about the labour market and Co‐op employers are also provided.
cmCourseInfo.title: Managing Your Job Search and Transition to Work
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: COPB51H3/(COPD03H3); restricted to students in the Arts and Science Co-op programs.

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Enrolment Control: E

Arts & Science Co-op department enrolls students into this course. Students cannot enroll via ACORN

Arts & Science Co-op students are automatically enrolled into the appropriate co-op courses each semester based on their program of study and co-op work term sequence. The Co-op course will begin the first week of classes. It is non-credit with no tuition fees attached. If you have any questions regarding your enrolment please contact askcoop@utoronto.ca

Students will be enrolled in the following sections based on their area of study:
LEC01 - Biochemistry, Chemistry, Biological Sciences, Environmental Sciences, Neuroscience, Molecular Biology & Biotechnology, Psychology, MHS, Health Studies - Population Health, Psycholinguistics, Linguistics, City Studies, Public Policy, Health Studies - Policy, English, French, History, Philosophy, Womenâ€™s Studies, Biochemistry, Chemistry, Biological Sciences, Environmental Sciences, Neuroscience, Molecular Biology & Biotechnology
LEC02 - Computer & Mathematical Sciences

PRA0002 is for students in Psychological & Health Sciences Psychology, Mental Health Studies, Psycholinguistics, Health Studies - Population Health, Neuroscience
PRA0003 is for students in English, History, French, Philosophy, Womenâ€™s Studies, City Studies, Public Policy, Health Studies - Policy, Linguistics
PRA0004 is for students in Computer Science Co-op, Mathematical Science Co-op and Statistics Co-op
PRA0005 is for students in Computer Science Co-op, Mathematical Science Co-op and Statistics Co-op

courses.name: Managing Your Ongoing Work Term Job Search

cmCourseInfo.description: This course is for students in Arts & Science Co-op who have undertaken a first work term search and successfully completed COPB52H3/(COPD11H3), but have not embarked on a first work term experience. Students in this course will continue with job search activities and receive additional support factoring in their overall learning.

courses.name: Integrating Your Work Term Experience Part I

cmCourseInfo.description: This course is designed to provide students who have completed their first work term with tools and strategies to effectively integrate their recent work term experience into their job search documents, as well as practice articulating their new or enhanced skills and experience in an interview setting. Students are provided with opportunities to practice and refine their approach as they begin to seek their next Co-op work term. In class Apply Together sessions and one-on-one appointment consultations with your Work Term Engagement Coordinator will provide you with semester specific market trends, tools and resources to succeed in your job search. There are also online and in person forums for sharing work term and job search experience with junior Co-op students and peers.
cmCourseInfo.title: Integrating Your Work Term Experience Part I
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: COPB52H3/(COPD11H3) and completion of one work term; restricted to students in the Arts and Science Co-op Programs.

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Enrolment Control: E

Arts & Science Co-op department enrolls students into this course. Students cannot enroll via ACORN

Arts & Science Co-op students are automatically enrolled into the appropriate co-op courses each semester based on their program of study and co-op work term sequence. Students will be enrolled in the following sections based on their area of study:
LEC01: Psychology, Mental Health Studies, Neuroscience, Health Studies, Biochemistry, Chemistry, Environmental Sciences, English, French, History, Philosophy, Linguistics, Psycholinguistics, Women's studies, City Studies, Public Policy, Conservation & Biodiversity
LEC02: Computer Science Co-op, Mathematics Co-op, Statistics Co-op

courses.name: Integrating Your Work Term Experience II

cmCourseInfo.description: This course is designed to provide students who have completed 2 work terms or more with tools and strategies to effectively integrate their recent work term experiences into their job search documents as well as practice articulating their new or enhanced skills and experience in an interview setting. Students are provided with opportunities to practice and refine their approach as they job search/compete for another Co-op work term. In class Apply Together sessions and one-on-one appointment consultations with your Work Term Engagement Coordinator will provide you with semester specific market trends, tools and resources to succeed in your job search. Having the experience of job searching and at least 8 months of work term experience, students share, compare, and contrast their individual experiences. There are also online and in person forums for sharing their work term and job search experience with junior Co-op students.
cmCourseInfo.title: Integrating Your Work Term Experience Part II
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: COPC98H3/(COPD12H3) and completion of at least two work terms; restricted to students in the Arts and Science Co-op programs.
cmCourseInfo.note: Students complete this course each time they are job searching for a work term beyond their second work term.

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Enrolment Control: E

Arts & Science Co-op department enrolls students into this course. Students cannot enroll via ACORN

Arts & Science Co-op students are automatically enrolled into the appropriate co-op courses each semester based on their program of study and co-op work term sequence. The Co-op course will begin the first week of classes. It is non-credit with no tuition fees attached. If you have any questions regarding your enrolment please contact askcoop@utoronto.ca

Students will be enrolled in the following sections based on their area of study:
LEC01: Psychology, Mental Health Studies, Neuroscience, Health Studies, Biochemistry, Chemistry, Environmental Sciences, English, French, History, Philosophy, Linguistics, Psycholinguistics, Women's studies, City Studies, Public Policy
LEC02 - Computer Science, Math, Statistics

courses.name: Integrating Your Work Term Experience II

cmCourseInfo.description: This course is designed to provide students who have completed 2 work terms or more with tools and strategies to effectively integrate their recent work term experiences into their job search documents as well as practice articulating their new or enhanced skills and experience in an interview setting. Students are provided with opportunities to practice and refine their approach as they job search/compete for another Co-op work term. In class Apply Together sessions and one-on-one appointment consultations with your Work Term Engagement Coordinator will provide you with semester specific market trends, tools and resources to succeed in your job search. Having the experience of job searching and at least 8 months of work term experience, students share, compare, and contrast their individual experiences. There are also online and in person forums for sharing their work term and job search experience with junior Co-op students.
cmCourseInfo.title: Integrating Your Work Term Experience Part II
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: COPC98H3/(COPD12H3) and completion of at least two work terms; restricted to students in the Arts and Science Co-op programs.
cmCourseInfo.note: Students complete this course each time they are job searching for a work term beyond their second work term.

Enrolment Control: E

Arts & Science Co-op department enrolls students into this course. Students cannot enroll via ACORN.



Arts & Science Co-op students are automatically enrolled into the appropriate co-op courses each semester based on their program of study and co-op work term sequence. The Co-op course will begin the first week of classes. It is non-credit with no tuition fees attached. If you have any questions regarding your enrolment please contact askcoop@utoronto.ca

Students will be enrolled in the following sections based on their area of study:
LEC01: Co-op programs in Biochemistry, Chemistry, Biological Chemistry, Environmental Science, Molecular Biology & Biotechnology and Humanities & Social Sciences, Psychology, Mental Health Studies and Neuroscience
